document_type: ISO 27001 Security Requirements - Annex A Control
applies_to_note: All gambling operators subject to RTS Chapter 4 - Security Requirements

control.control_purpose: To produce, store, protect and analyse logs of activity, exceptions, faults and relevant events to record evidence, ensure log integrity, prevent unauthorised access and support investigations
control.control_objective: Establish comprehensive logging mechanisms that record system activities, user actions and security-relevant events in a manner that maintains integrity, prevents tampering and enables identification and investigation of security incidents

iso_27001_definition.official_text: Logs that record activities, exceptions, faults and other relevant events should be produced, stored, protected and analysed.
key_requirements: Production of logs recording activities, exceptions, faults and relevant events
Storage of logs with appropriate protection mechanisms
Protection of log data from unauthorised access and modification
Analysis of logs to identify security events and patterns
Detective control designed to record events and generate evidence
Assurance of log integrity and prevention of tampering including by privileged users
Support for investigations and formal proceedings

control_purpose_detail.purpose: Detective control functioning in conjunction with preventive controls to record what has occurred, generate evidence and enable forensic investigation
scope: All systems processing, storing or transmitting gambling-related data
All applications and infrastructure supporting gambling operations
control_purpose_detail.key_outcome: Comprehensive audit trail enabling investigation of incidents and demonstration of compliance

prerequisites.description: Before implementing logging, foundational requirements must be met

required_prerequisites.rationale: Logging requirements identified through risk assessment
required_prerequisites.reference: ISO 27001 A 5.12 - Information and other asset classification

required_prerequisites.rationale: Classification levels determine logging requirements and retention

required_prerequisites.description: Complete inventory of systems and assets
required_prerequisites.rationale: Must know what systems exist to determine logging requirements
required_prerequisites.reference: ISO 27001 A 5.9 - Inventory of information and other associated assets

required_prerequisites.description: Understanding of applicable data protection laws
required_prerequisites.rationale: Logging practices must comply with data protection requirements

implementation_requirements.description: Identify what requirements exist for logging based on risk assessment, business needs and legal obligations

basis_for_requirements: Results of information security risk assessment
Support for formal investigations and legal proceedings
requirement_identification: Conduct formal risk assessment identifying systems requiring logging
Document legal and regulatory requirements for logging

implementation_requirements.description: Develop comprehensive topic-specific policy governing logging lifecycle

policy_content: Scope of logging and systems covered
Events and activities to be logged
policy_requirements: Reviewed and updated at least annually

implementation_requirements.requirement: Define Event Log Fields and Content
implementation_requirements.description: Specify mandatory fields and required events to be logged

mandatory_log_fields: User ID - unique identification of person performing action
System activities - description of what occurred
Dates and times - with sufficient precision and synchronisation
Device identity and system identifier - source of log entry
Network addresses and protocols - communication path information
events_to_be_logged: Successful and rejected system access attempts
Use of privileges and privilege elevation
Use of utility programs and administrative tools
Files accessed and type of access including deletions
Alarms raised by access control systems
Activation and deactivation of security systems
Creation, modification or deletion of identities
Transactions executed by users in applications
field_specifications: User identification must be unique and traceable
Timestamps must have sufficient precision for event correlation
System activities must be recorded with sufficient detail for investigation
Device and network information must identify the source system clearly

implementation_requirements.requirement: Protect Logs from Unauthorised Access and Modification
implementation_requirements.description: Implement technical and administrative controls to protect log integrity

technical_controls: Encryption of logs at rest and in transit
Access controls restricting log access to authorised personnel only
Write-once storage or immutability preventing modification
Log aggregation to centralised systems with segregated access
Digital signatures or cryptographic techniques ensuring integrity
Redundant storage preventing loss through system failure
administrative_controls: Segregation of duties between log generators and log administrators
Policies requiring authorisation for log access
Documented procedures for log retention and deletion
Audit trails recording all access to logs
privileged_user_protection: Logs protected even from system administrators
Log immutability preventing modification by privileged users
Separate protection for privileged user action logs

implementation_requirements.description: Implement logging practices that comply with applicable data protection laws

compliance_requirements: Identify lawful basis for collecting personal data in logs
Implement data minimisation - log only necessary personal data
Define retention periods based on legal requirements and necessity
Establish procedures for fulfilling data subject rights requests
Implement automated deletion of logs when retention expires
Maintain data processing agreements for third-party log sharing
data_protection_considerations: Logs may contain personal data protected by GDPR and Data Protection Act 2018
Personal data in logs must be processed lawfully
Data subjects must be informed about logging through privacy notices
Retention must be limited to necessary periods
Data deletion procedures must be implemented and enforced
professional_guidance: Obtain legal and data protection professional advice on logging implementation

implementation_requirements.description: Establish procedures and capabilities for analysing logs to identify security events

analysis_expertise: Personnel performing analysis must have appropriate expertise and skills
Understanding of systems generating logs required
Knowledge of security incidents and attack patterns required
Training and development provided for analysis staff
analysis_procedures: Documented procedures defining log analysis approach
Tools and techniques identified for analysis
analysis_techniques: Rule-based exception detection using SIEM, firewall or IDS
Behavioural analytics using UEBA to detect anomalies
Pattern and trend analysis using data analytics techniques
Threat intelligence integration to detect known threats
Identification of security event attributes indicating incidents

implementation_requirements.description: Implement specific monitoring activities based on identified needs

monitoring_activities: Access to protected resources - successful and failed attempts
Outbound network connections - detection of malicious server access
Service provider reports - monitoring for security events
Physical security events - access, locations and CCTV
Transaction processing - verification of correct execution
monitoring_frequency: Critical systems - continuous or near-continuous monitoring
Important systems - at least daily monitoring
Standard systems - weekly or monthly monitoring
Frequency based on risk assessment and criticality
alerting_and_escalation: Formal alerting procedures when suspicious events detected
Triaging of alerts to determine investigation need
High-severity alert escalation to incident response teams
Recording and tracking of all alerts

implementation_requirements.description: Establish and enforce log retention periods with automated deletion

retention_determination: Retention periods based on regulatory requirements
Retention periods based on business needs
Retention periods based on legal requirements
Different retention for different log types
Retention aligned with data protection requirements
deletion_procedures: Automated deletion when retention period expires
Evidence that deletion is occurring as scheduled
No manual intervention required for standard deletion
retention_periods: Regulatory reports - as required by applicable laws

steps.detail: Complete risk assessment and identify all logging requirements
Create comprehensive policy governing logging lifecycle

steps.action: Assess current systems and identify gaps
steps.detail: Determine current logging capabilities and gaps against requirements
Configure systems to generate required logs with mandatory fields
Deploy SIEM or log aggregation system
Deploy encryption, access controls and immutability
Define procedures and rules for log analysis
Provide training on logging requirements and procedures
Verify all required events are being captured and protected

compliance_checklist.description: Steps to comply with ISO 27001 Annex A 8.15

checklist.item: Risk assessment identifying logging requirements completed
Logging and Monitoring Policy documented and approved
Log field requirements defined (user ID, timestamp, system activity, device identity, network information)
Logging requirements specification documented for all systems
All systems configured to generate required logs
Log protection mechanisms implemented (encryption, access controls, immutability)
Log retention policies defined and implemented
Log analysis procedures documented and implemented
Internal audits conducted verifying logging operation
Incident investigation procedures incorporate log analysis

common_mistakes.description: Top 3 mistakes organizations make with logging

mistakes.mistake: Collecting excessive log data without strategic purpose
mistakes.description: Logging everything without understanding what is valuable or analysable, resulting in overwhelming data volumes, complex analysis and retention burdens
root_cause: Failure to identify specific logging requirements through risk assessment
Assumption that more logging is always better without understanding analysis capability
Technical configuration without governance or oversight
Lack of data protection expertise in determining necessity
mistakes.impact: Infrastructure strain, analysis paralysis, inability to respond to alerts, data retention burdens, potential data protection violations
prevention: Conduct formal risk assessment identifying specific requirements
Define clear business objectives for each log type
Determine what can realistically be analysed with available resources
Implement log retention policies automatically deleting logs when no longer needed
Engage data protection professional for compliance review
Monitor log volume and storage costs for escalation

mistakes.mistake: Ignoring legal and data protection obligations
mistakes.description: Implementing logging without considering data protection law requirements, leading to unlawful processing of personal data and regulatory violation
root_cause: Lack of data protection expertise in logging design
Assumption that security requirements override data protection requirements
Cost-cutting that eliminates legal and data protection review
Failure to maintain records of lawful basis for processing
Inadequate data processing agreements with third parties
mistakes.impact: Regulatory enforcement action by UKGC and ICO, fines, reputational damage, loss of customer trust, compliance violations
prevention: Engage data protection professional during requirements definition
Document lawful basis for collecting personal data before implementation
Implement controls limiting personal data collection to necessary information only
Establish retention periods based on legal requirements and necessity
Develop data subject access request procedures for GDPR compliance
Establish data processing agreements before sharing logs with third parties

mistakes.mistake: Poor document and version control for logging policies
mistakes.description: Failure to maintain proper documentation and version control creating confusion about current requirements and preventing effective implementation
root_cause: Lack of formal document management procedures
No designated responsibility for version control
Failure to distinguish working drafts from approved versions
No requirement for formal approval before implementation
Inadequate records of policy reviews and updates
mistakes.impact: Uncertainty about current requirements, inconsistent implementation, inability to audit compliance, failed audits
prevention: Establish formal document management procedures for version control
Designate specific responsibility for maintaining current versions
Implement document numbering scheme with visible version numbers
Require formal approval before implementation of changes
Maintain dated records of all policy reviews and updates
Archive superseded versions with clear dates and reasons
Ensure staff access only current approved versions

audit_requirements.description: What auditors will check during ISO 27001 A 8.15 audit

audit_areas.description: Verify documented logging requirements and approved policy
checks: Risk assessment identifying logging requirements exists
Logging and Monitoring Policy documented and formally approved
Data protection compliance documented
Information classification scheme addresses logging implications
Document version control maintained with evidence of recent review

audit_areas.description: Verify logs are being produced with required content
checks: All required systems configured to generate logs
Logs contain mandatory fields (user ID, timestamp, system activity, device identity, network information)
All required events being logged (access attempts, privilege use, configuration changes, file access)
Timestamps accurate and synchronised across systems
User identification accurate and unique
Cloud provider logs being collected

audit_areas.description: Verify logs are protected from unauthorised access and modification
checks: Access controls preventing unauthorised log access
Logs protected from modification after creation
Encryption enabled for log storage and transmission
Segregation of duties between log generators and administrators
Privileged user actions specially monitored and protected
Access audit trails maintained recording all log access

audit_areas.description: Verify logs are being analysed and monitored
checks: Log analysis procedures documented and implemented
Personnel performing analysis have appropriate expertise
SIEM or equivalent analysis tool implemented
Analysis rules current and aligned with threat landscape
Monitoring performed on defined schedule
Alerts generated for suspicious events with documented responses
Threat intelligence integrated into analysis

audit_areas.description: Verify logging complies with data protection requirements
checks: Lawful basis for collecting personal data documented
Retention periods defined and justified
Logs deleted when retention period expires
Data protection impact assessment performed
Data subject access procedures in place
Data processing agreements in place for third-party log sharing
Privacy notice addresses logging

audit_areas.description: Verify incident response incorporates log analysis
checks: Incident response procedures incorporate log analysis
Log evidence preserved during investigations
Investigation records document log findings
Root cause analysis uses log data
Corrective actions based on log findings documented
Transaction logging for all gambling transactions
Customer account modification logging
Fund transfer logging
Dispute resolution logging
Payment provider logging
Regulatory reporting supported by logs

ukgc_application.critical_systems_context: For UK Gambling Commission compliance, logging is a critical control that must operate across all systems handling customer funds, personal information and gambling activities. UKGC auditors examine gambling transaction logs, customer account modifications and fund transfers to verify controls are effective. Logging must support UKGC's ability to investigate complaints, disputes and compliance breaches.
specific_requirements: Comprehensive transaction logging for all customer wagers, game outcomes, payouts and account changes with timestamp, user, transaction details and result
Customer account modification logging recording all account changes including creation, updates and closure
Privileged user activity logging with special protection enabling detection of unauthorized access or misuse
Access logging for customer personal information enabling investigation of data breaches
Payment provider interaction logging including authorizations, notifications and disputes
Log retention for 2-5 years enabling investigation of historical events and UKGC inquiries
Log analysis specifically monitoring for fraud indicators including unusual wager patterns and suspicious access
Third-party service provider logging contractually required and audited
Data protection compliance incorporated into logging practices
ukgc_application.compliance_requirement: Gambling operators must implement comprehensive logging across all critical systems, maintain logs in protected storage, perform regular analysis, retain logs for sufficient periods and demonstrate through logs that other controls operate effectively

compliance_notes.overall_purpose: Create auditable record of all material system activities, user actions and transactions enabling compliance demonstration, breach investigation and UKGC response
compliance_notes.enforcement_priority: Critical - UKGC considers logging high-priority; auditors specifically examine logging implementations and frequently identify deficiencies
key_principles: Comprehensiveness - logging sufficient to investigate any material event
Integrity - logs accurate and protected from tampering
Timeliness - logs analysed regularly and suspicious events investigated promptly
Retention - logs retained long enough to enable historical investigation
Protection - logs protected from unauthorised access including by administrators
Purpose-alignment - logging aligned with identified risks and regulatory requirements

All required events logged: access attempts, privilege use, configuration changes, customer account modifications and transaction execution
Logs protected from unauthorised access and modification with technical and administrative controls
Data protection compliance documented including lawful basis, retention periods and deletion procedures
Log analysis procedures documented and performed regularly to detect security events
Personnel performing analysis with appropriate expertise and training
SIEM or equivalent analysis system with current rules detecting known threats and anomalies
Monitoring performed on defined schedule appropriate to system criticality
Alerts generated for suspicious events with documented responses
Segregation of duties between log generators and administrators
Log access audit trails maintained showing all access
Internal audits conducted at least annually verifying control effectiveness
Audit findings documented with evidence of remediation
Incident investigations incorporating log analysis with documented evidence usage
Gambling-specific logging for transactions, customer accounts and fund transfers
Log retention policies implemented and automatically enforced
Evidence that logs have been used to investigate breaches and determine actions

related_requirements.rts_reference: UK Gambling Commission Remote Technical Standards (RTS) Chapter 4 - Systems and Operational Security

related_controls.relationship: Logging provides evidence that access controls operate effectively
Logging of authentication attempts detects and investigates potential breaches
Logging of privilege elevation detects unauthorized privilege use
Logs must identify users; requires unique user identification implementation
Access control logs verify controls are operating and detect failures
Logs provide source data for event monitoring and analysis
Logging records use of utility programs and administrative tools
Logs are primary evidence source for investigating incidents

technical_best_practices: Implement centralised logging with SIEM system collecting logs from all sources
Use syslog protocol for standardised log transmission between systems
Encrypt logs at rest and in transit to prevent unauthorised access
Implement write-once storage preventing modification of historical logs
Use cryptographic techniques to verify log integrity and detect tampering
Maintain redundant log copies in geographically separate locations
Ensure log entries are written atomically to prevent partial or corrupted entries
Use structured logging formats (JSON, XML) enabling automated parsing
Implement real-time alerting for critical events enabling rapid response
Configure SIEM to correlate events across systems detecting complex attack patterns
process_best_practices: Establish logging management committee overseeing logging strategy
Implement formal change management for logging configuration changes
Conduct quarterly log architecture reviews verifying continued compliance
Establish differentiated retention schedules by log type optimizing storage
Implement automated log deletion when retention periods expire
Establish log access request and approval process preventing misuse
Maintain detailed log access audit trails detecting unauthorized access
Conduct quarterly reviews of log analysis results assessing effectiveness
Define specific escalation procedures for critical event severity levels
Maintain incident investigation playbooks documenting standard procedures
awareness_best_practices: Conduct annual logging policy training for all staff
Provide specialist training for log analysis personnel on SIEM tools and attack patterns
Train system administrators on logging requirements for their systems
Train incident response team on using logs for investigation
Ensure third-party service providers understand logging requirements
Publish internal guidance on logging best practices for system owners
monitoring_best_practices: Monitor log volume and storage consumption trends monthly
Monitor alert volume and signal-to-noise ratio identifying excessive false alarms
Track log analysis coverage identifying gaps
Maintain metrics on investigation outcomes showing log analysis effectiveness
Conduct annual capacity planning for future log volume and storage
Review and update SIEM rules annually for new threats
Benchmark against industry best practices and improve implementation
Participate in security forums learning from peers

gambling_operator_specific_guidance.customer_transaction_logging: Comprehensive logging of all customer transactions is mandatory for UKGC compliance. Log all wagers placed, game results, winnings, payouts and account balance changes. Record customer ID, timestamp, transaction type, transaction amount, game identifier, transaction result and exceptions. Transaction logs are primary evidence for anti-money laundering, responsible gambling and accurate accounting compliance. Retain transaction logs for at least five years.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.customer_account_security_logging: Log all account access with timestamp, user ID and result. Log all account modifications including information updates, deposit/withdrawal requests, restrictions and closure. Log security setting changes including password changes and authentication setup. Alert on unusual access patterns including access from unusual locations or multiple failed attempts. Unusual patterns should trigger investigation.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.payment_processing_logging: Log all payment authorizations, confirmations and failures. Record payment processor responses including codes and settlement confirmations. Log payment disputes and chargebacks with detailed information and resolution. Log payment processor connections and data transmission. Flag rejected or failed payments for investigation.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.fraud_detection_through_logging: Use transaction logs to detect fraud indicators including rapid wager escalation, unusual betting patterns, access from multiple locations, rapid deposits and withdrawals, and inconsistent account patterns. Configure SIEM rules to alert on fraud indicators automatically. Conduct log-based fraud investigations when indicators are detected.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.responsible_gambling_logging: Log customer account restrictions including deposit limits, loss limits, time-out periods and self-exclusion requests. Log enforcement of restrictions including blocked transactions. Log age and identity verification results. Log any override of responsible gambling restrictions with justification and approval.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.audit_trail_for_regulatory_reporting: Support regulatory reports with audit trails showing data derivation. Reports should reference underlying transaction logs. Maintain ability to retrieve log evidence supporting specific transactions or customers. Logs must reconcile with reported figures.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.dispute_resolution_logging: Log customer dispute complaints with details, date received and complainant information. Log dispute investigation showing evidence reviewed and conclusions. Log dispute resolutions with decision and justification. Log any claim payments. Logs enable demonstration to UKGC that disputes were investigated fairly.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.third_party_service_provider_logging: Incorporate logging requirements into service agreements. Make logs contractually available to the operator. Verify third parties are logging required events. Integrate third-party logs into centralised logging system where possible.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.audit_readiness_for_gambling_operators: Maintain current documented Logging and Monitoring Policy approved by management. Implement comprehensive logging for all customer-facing and transaction systems. Conduct regular log analysis with documented results. Maintain logs of all privileged user access to sensitive systems. Retain logs for sufficiently long periods to support investigations. Implement automated testing to verify logging is functioning. Maintain documentation showing how logs support regulatory compliance. Prepare quarterly summaries of log-based security activities for management review.
